intro: Loeseneriella africana var. richardiana, commonly known as the African moonflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night. The plant produces violet-colored berries that contain toxic compounds, making it potentially harmful to animals and humans. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in woodland or savanna habitats. Its unique blooming pattern and ornamental value make it a subject of interest in botanical studies and horticulture.
